title: Big Brother Australia 'will compete with Married At First Sight in Channel Seven reboot'
text:
Married At First Sight is the biggest reality show in Australia.

But now it looks like Nine's golden goose may have competition as Channel Seven looks set to launch a reboot of Big Brother Australia in the same time slot next year.

According to TV Blackbox, Channel Seven will bring the controversial reality show back in February 2020 to directly compete against MAFS.

New frontrunner? Nine's Married At First Sight may have competition amid rumours Channel Seven is launching a reboot of Big Brother Australia. Pictured: Bronson Norrish and Ines Basic

It's expected to replace My Kitchen Rules after the next series of the cooking show was postponed.

As Channel Seven's biggest reality offering, MKR was expected to come back for another series but now it seems the network has had a change of heart.

Instead, it seems Seven is preparing to take a punt with Big Brother after a five-year hiatus, no doubt hoping it can knock MAFS off the top spot.

Comeback? Former Big Brother host Gretel Killeen (pictured) recently spoke about a potential return of Big Brother Australia on KIIS FM

In April, MAFS blitzed its own ratings record, drawing a blockbuster national audience of 2.61 million.

And the season's conclusion topped charts as the highest-rated MAFS finale in history, with a staggering 1.96 million metro viewers tuning in.

Channel Seven is yet to confirm or deny whether it will be hosting the reboot of Big Brother next year.

New home? The landmark reality show, previously filmed at Queensland's Dreamworld theme park, first premiered back in 2001 and continued for eight seasons

Daily Mail Australia has contacted the channel for comment.

Meanwhile, Endemol Shine Australia is said to be producing the show once again and has already begun casting for next year's series.

It's thought filming for the next series will take place in Sydney, after the previous Big Brother house was destroyed in a fire.

The landmark reality show, previously filmed at Queensland's Dreamworld theme park, first premiered back in 2001 and continued for eight seasons.

Following a significant fall in ratings and a few controversies, including an alleged sexual assault in 2006, Channel 10 decided not renew the series.

Former Big Brother host Gretel Killeen, 56, recently spoke about a potential return of Big Brother Australia on KIIS FM.

'I think it would be a hoot!' she said, but refused to confirm or deny whether she would be making a comeback.
description: Married At First Sight is the biggest reality show in Australia.
authors: Jess Bell For Daily Mail Australia
